story: Although different variations of coffee cocktails pre-date the now-classic Irish coffee by at least 100 years, the original Irish coffee was according to sources invented and named by Joe Sheridan, a head chef at Foynes, County Limerick but originally from Castlederg, County Tyrone. Foynes' port was the precursor to Shannon International Airport in the west of Ireland; the coffee was conceived after a group of American passengers disembarked from a Pan Am flying boat on a miserable winter evening in the 1940s. Sheridan added whiskey to the coffee to warm the passengers. After the passengers asked if they were being served Brazilian coffee, Sheridan told them it was "Irish coffee".

story: The Rob Roy is a cocktail created in 1894 by a bartender at the Waldorf Hotel in New York City. The drink was named in honor of the premiere of Rob Roy, an operetta by composer Reginald De Koven and lyricist Harry B. Smith loosely based upon Scottish folk hero Robert Roy MacGregor. The Rob Roy is similar to a Manhattan but is made exclusively with Scotch whisky, while the Manhattan is traditionally made with rye.

story: A good host or hostess thinks of everyone - don't be one of those people scrounging around in the back of the fridge for a sole diet soda. Have a plan for the non-alcholic drinks before the guests arrive. If you're prepared for mixed drinks, you've likely got a good base for making nice mocktails: juices, soft drinks, ice and fresh fruit will take you far. And experimenting is so much cheaper than with alcoholic drinks!

story: The beauty of the ABSOLUT range is that the tastes are so pure they can easily be exchanged in almost any recipe. Take the Applebreeze, for instance. Try any flavor and the cocktail is brilliant in a different way. Everything from ABSOLUT VANILIA to ABSOLUT PEARS to ABSOLUT RASPBERRI works great. Experiment to find your favorite!

story: The mint julep originated in the southern United States, probably during the eighteenth century. U.S. Senator Henry Clay of Kentucky introduced the drink to Washington, D.C., at the Round Robin Bar in the famous Willard Hotel during his residence in the city. Each year almost 120,000 juleps are served at Churchill Downs over the two-day period of the Kentucky Oaks and the Kentucky Derby, virtually all of them in specially made Kentucky Derby collectible glasses.

descriptionPlain: Muddle mint leaf and simple syrup in a chilled rocks glass. Fill with crushed ice. Add bourbon.

story: Pimm's was first produced in 1823 by James Pimm, a farmer's son from Kent who became the owner of an oyster bar in the City of London, near the Bank of England. Pimm offered the tonic (a gin-based drink containing quinine and a secret mixture of herbs) as an aid to digestion, serving it in a small tankard known as a "No. 1 Cup", hence its subsequent name.

story: The Clover Club once was a gentleman's hangout in Philadelphia, and records show that a drink with the same name was known already at the beginning of the 1900s. But on the other side of Prohibition (1920--1933) the Clover Club seems to have been almost forgotten. Today, it's been rediscovered, but our version holds vodka instead of the original gin.

story: The perfect way to make an Old-Fashioned has been disputed, but one thing is clear. Never was it more needed then during prohibition; it's the best way ever invented to improve the taste of bad liquor. Now made with the purest of ingredients, it's a helluva classy drink. Traditionally bourbon-based, it's something new with ABSOLUT.

That was until someone came up with the Moscow Mule and started serving it in special copper mugs as a gimmick. Once Hollywood celebrities picked it up, the Moscow Mule hit was a fact. story: Henry C. Ramos invented the Ramos Gin Fizz in 1888 at his bar, the Imperial Cabinet Saloonin on Gravier Street, New Orleans, Louisiana. It was originally called the New Orleans Fizz, and is one of the city's most famous cocktails. Before Prohibition, the bar was known to have over 20 bartenders working at once, making nothing but the Ramos Gin Fizz - and still struggling to keep up with the demand. During the carnival of 1915, 32 staff were on at once, just to shake the drink. The drink's long mixing time (12 minutes) made it a very time consuming cocktail to produce.

story:
Making home-made flavored syrups is actually really easy, and a great way to create unique flavor combinations.

STRAWBERRY AND BLACK PEPPERCORN SYRUP

1 cup caster sugar
Â½ cup water
20 washed, hulled and halved ripe strawberries
1 tablespoon crushed black peppercorns

Let all ingredients simmer in a pan for 15 minutes, cool off and sieve into a bottle. Keeps for up to two weeks in the fridge.

story:
Making home-made flavored syrups is actually really easy, and a great way to create unique flavor combinations.

PEACH AND CARAWAY SYRUP RECIPE

4 ripe, fresh peaches (stoned and quartered)
1 cup caster sugar
1 teaspoon caraway seed
Â½ cup water

Let all ingredients simmer in a pan for 15 minutes, cool off and sieve into a bottle. Keeps for up to two weeks in the fridge.

story: L.O Smith was the founder of ABSOLUT. At the age of ten he is said to have doubled the income at store he worked at. He went into the liquor business in his 20s and by 1879, the king of Spirits started this brand. You see his portrait on all ABSOLUT bottles, where he no doubt watches your proportions in this tribute punch. So do it right!

story: ABSOLUT RUBY RED was introduced in 2006, just a few years after the success with the other citrus flavored members of the family ABSOLUT CITRON and ABSOLUT MANDRIN. The name ABSOLUT RUBY RED is taken from a special kind of red grapefruit. And grapefruit is of course what it tastes like! It is made exclusively from natural ingredients, and unlike most other flavored vodkas, it doesnâ€™t contain any added sugar. ABSOLUT RUBY RED is smooth and fruity with a crisp and refreshing character of zesty grapefruit.

story: Around 1850, Sewell T. Taylor sold his bar, The Merchants Exchange Coffee House, and went into the imported liquor business. He began to import a brand of cognac named Sazerac-de-Forge et Fils. At the same time, Aaron Bird took over the Merchants Exchange and changed its name to the Sazerac House and began serving the "Sazerac Cocktail", made with Taylor's Sazerac cognac and, legend has it, the bitters being made down the street by a local druggist, Antoine Amedie Peychaud.
